pages.text: Funisia dorothea comes from the upper Ediacaran, with fossils found in the Rawnsley Quartzite, Australia. It is the largest olgunid, growing up to 30 cm in height. It superficially resembles and upright worm, although the similarities end there, as it bears a small holdfast at its base, and has been postured to have affinities to sponges. It is also currently the oldest known animal to sexually reproduce, although could still reproduce via budding.

The generic name derives directly from the Latin word 'Funisia', to mean 'rope'. The specific name derives from the Latinised forename of Dorothy Droser, mother to Mary L. Droser, one of the palaeontologists that studied the first specimens of Funisia.
